docs.lead_paragraph: For many students, something happens in the short time between their arrival in middle school in the fall and the following spring -- and it is not good. In a recently released study, 12.8 percent of newly arriving middle school students said they had tried tobacco. Just six months later, the figure was 15.2 percent.

headline.main: When Teenagers Smoke: A Closer Look

docs.abstract: American Legacy Foundation study finds 15.2 percent of students report having tried tobacco six months after entering middle school, up from 12.8 percent of newly arrived middle school students; photo (S)
docs.snippet: For many students, something happens in the short time between their arrival in middle school in the fall and the following spring -- and it is not good.    In a recently released study, 12.8 percent of newly arriving middle school students said they...

docs.lead_paragraph: My parents certainly meant well when they wheedled and cajoled and bribed their then-scrawny preschooler to eat the nutritious foods they served. So did my grandmother when she fed me sticks of butter, bars of cheese and cans of evaporated milk to fatten me up. Their well-intentioned efforts produced a child-cum-adult who equates food with love and can eat with abandon when she feels anxious or unloved.

headline.main: Show Children Love, With a Carrot Stick

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on encouraging healthy eating in children; says studies show that pressuring children to eat some foods and restricting their access to others have same negative consequences; notes children learn parents' eating habits; holds they should be offered variety of healthful foods and snacks; holds mealtimes should be enjoyable experiences, not battlegrounds; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Salmonella, the bacteria that can cause food poisoning and even death, may have the potential to help certain cancer patients. Researchers at the Yale School of Medicine say the bacteria appears to help combat melanoma, especially when it is used in conjunction with standard radiation therapy.

headline.main: The Evil Salmonella and Its Helpful Twin

docs.abstract: Yale medical school researchers report that salmonella, bacteria that causes food poisoning, seems to help combat melanoma, especially when used with standard radiation therapy; clinical trials are under way to make sure nontoxic strain of bacteria developed for study in mice is not harmful to people (S)
docs.snippet: Salmonella, the bacteria that can cause food poisoning and even death, may have the potential to help certain cancer patients.    Researchers at the Yale School of Medicine say the bacteria appears to help combat melanoma, especially when it is used...

docs.lead_paragraph: When I first met Mr. J. in my office he looked terrible -- anxious, exhausted, demoralized. He had stopped going to work several days earlier and was mostly staying in bed. After taking his history, I recommended psychotherapy and medication for his depression. But he would not consider taking medication. He wanted to deal with his depression, he said, ''without depending on drugs.'' Perhaps because I had been an internist for several years before becoming a psychiatrist, I was baffled by his response. In medicine the situation had been exactly the reverse. There was huge pressure to hand out prescriptions for every cough and sniffle, even when it made no real sense. ''Do something to make me feel better, now,'' was the unspoken mandate. When a patient left my office empty-handed, it was often with a palpable sense of disappointment.
docs.abstract: Dr Anna Fels article says some patients are reluctant to take antidepressant drugs because for them it is tantamount to ceding the supremacy of consciousness in controlling who they are and what they do (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Jennifer Weinstein is only 29 years old. But she was anxious about the possibility that the child she was carrying might be afflicted with Down syndrome or a neural tube defect and was debating whether to undergo amniocentesis to check on the well-being of the fetus. Instead, she joined a large collaborative study called the Faster Trial, which is exploring new, safer and less costly ways of predicting which babies might be born with Down syndrome.

headline.main: Experts Explore Safer Tests for Down Syndrome

docs.abstract: Several large studies are now under way of new prenatal tests for Down syndrome that are expected to substantially cut number of pregnant women who undergo amniocentesis; new tests could make it possible to accurately screen all pregnant women, not just those over 35 who face increased risk of having child with syndrome, chomosomal abnormality; so-called triple screen, three tests of maternal blood performed during second trimester of pregnancy, is already widely used among women of all ages; table of possible tests; graphs of error rate by test and of miscarriages by test; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Jennifer Weinstein is only 29 years old. But she was anxious about the possibility that the child she was carrying might be afflicted with Down syndrome or a neural tube defect and was debating whether to undergo amniocentesis to check on the...

docs.lead_paragraph: Geologists have developed maps showing which parts of Southern California are most vulnerable to shaking during earthquakes. Structures built on soft sediments in valleys and basins surrounded by mountains would, under certain conditions, shake more than twice as much as would structures built on harder rocks. Shaking is also more likely in areas where these soft sediments are deepest, including a four-mile-deep basin south of downtown Los Angeles, a six-mile-deep basin on the northern edge of the San Fernando Valley and a 10-mile-deep basin in Ventura County. The map above is of the Los Angeles area. But because each earthquake is unique, actual patterns of shaking and structural damage will vary greatly.

headline.main: Maps Point to 'Hot Spots' In Southern California

docs.abstract: Geologists have developed maps showing which parts of Southern California are most vulnerable to shaking during earthquakes; map (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: A national survey of primary care doctors suggests that many are doing little to help drug-addicted patients conquer their addiction. About one-third of the 1,080 doctors surveyed said they did not routinely ask new patients if they used illicit drugs, and 15 percent said they did not routinely offer any intervention to the patients who said they used drugs.

headline.main: Doctors Don't Always Address Drug Abuse

docs.abstract: National survey of primary care doctors suggests many are doing little to help patients conquer drug addiction; finds only 55 percent of doctors who offer intervention recommend formal addiction therapy (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Want to live to be 100? No problem, a new study suggests. Just find a mother or father who already has.

headline.main: Centenarians' Secret: It's in the Blood

docs.abstract: Study by Dr Nir Y Barzilai finds both centenarians and their children have unusually healthy cholesterol levels, suggesting children may enjoy same longevity; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Want to live to be 100?     No problem, a new study suggests. Just find a mother or father who already has.

docs.lead_paragraph: Numerous studies have suggested a link between what children watch on television or what video games they play and how they behave. The more violent the fare, the studies have said, the more aggressive the children. Now researchers at Stanford University say they have hit on a rather straightforward way to reverse the process a bit: have the children spend less time in front of the television or video games.

headline.main: Curbing Aggression With the Off Switch

docs.abstract: Stanford University study find reducing children's exposure to television and video games seems to curb aggressive behavior; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Numerous studies have suggested a link between what children watch on television or what video games they play and how they behave. The more violent the fare, the studies have said, the more aggressive the children.    Now researchers at Stanford...

docs.lead_paragraph: It has been well established that when it comes to receiving medical care, blacks often do not receive the same quality of treatment as whites. So what explains a recent finding that black patients being treated at Veterans Administration hospitals had lower mortality rates for six common diseases than white patients?

headline.main: With V.A., a Healthy Turn for Blacks

docs.abstract: Researchers are unable to explain why black patients being treated at Veterans Affairs hospitals were found to have lower mortality rates for six common diseases than white patients (S)
